Award.AwardTitle: Optimal Spatiotemporal Reduced Order Modeling for Nonlinear Structural Dynamics

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The overall goal of this project is to formulate optimal, data driven, reduced order modeling (ROM) frameworks for significantly faster and more accurate computational predictions of nonlinear dynamical systems. The modeling framework is based upon the optimal prediction formalism and includes information in the form of relevant spatiotemporal correlations. To achieve the overall project goal, the work will a) apply the method to variational (weak) forms and b) investigate, using the ROM methodology and fully resolved simulation, two problems in nonlinear structural dynamics which are expected to exhibit complex spatial and temporal (scale) characteristics. The two specific problems to be investigated are: 1) turbulent behavior of isotropic plate vibration and 2) vibration characteristics of three-dimensional continua with anisotropic constitutive relationships.

Reduced order modeling is an integral part of the engineering design process as fully resolved simulation is still too expensive to be practical for parametric and optimization studies. The advances in reduced order simulation provided by the work will have significant impact on the ability to provide fast and reliable simulation to aid in the innovation of new engineering products. Results and ideas generated from the project will be disseminated through peer-reviewed publication and conference attendance. In order to introduce students to the important concept of reduced order simulation, a new graduate level course on the subject will be developed at The University of Oklahoma. To further broaden the impact of the work, underrepresented groups (undergraduates in general, women and minority students) will be actively recruited to participate both directly in the research activities and indirectly through a new course.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall goal of this project was to formulate optimal, data-driven, reduced order models (ROMS) for significantly faster and more reliable computational predictions of nonlinear dynamical systems. These ROMS have the capability of improving the state-of-art in weak form based numerical discretizations.

Most currently used ROMs in fields such as nonlinear structural dynamics, which are often based upon weak forms, do not consider the effects of the unresolved (temporal and spatial) scales on the resolved scales . Our work provides a methodology for including this important information through the use of data-driven subgrid models, which are based upon error minimization principles, and will hopefully motivate other researchers in this area to consider the concepts introduced in our work in their future research.

Our ROM forms include the possibility of considering both current and past information (history), a concept which can be used to improve simulation accuracy and efficiency in many Engineering disciplines including the underresolved prediction of turbulent flows (large eddy simulation e.g. LES). Model forms investigated included a reduced polynomial (RPS-model; reduction based upon strain-displacement relationships for geometriclly nonlinear continuum mechanics) and a physics based model form (R-model). Two different methods for developing subgrid model in terms of error minimization were investigated. The first involves using apriori error minimization between the residual and the model for the residual (tau-error). The second (D-error) involves using aposteriori error, over a number of timesteps, between the filtered kinematic fields and the computed (with the subgrid model) kinematic fields. 

Our methodology was tested using a problem in nonlinear structural dynamics which consisted of a thin plate under a periodic point load. Multiple spatial and temporal scales were induced by the geometric nonlinearity of the plate, which was modeled using a finite element discretization based upon multi-field weak form. This problem was investigated numerically using both fully resolved simulation (FRS), which was used to both collect the spatiotemporal statistics necessary to construct the models and for aposteriori comparison, and underresolved model both with and without subgrid models. 

The following are some significant specific results for the problem simulated:

 a) For all model forms and minimization methods, ROMS with vastly reduced resolution (4 orders of magnitude fewer elements in comparison with fully resolved models and an order of magnitude reduction in temporal resolution) were able to be identified which were able to improve upon the results for computational models with same resolution but with no subgrid models.

b) The R-model form, constructed using the D-error minimization procedure, produced results which best matched the filtered FRS results.

c) The D-error and tau-error minimizations, in combination with the RPS model form, produced ROMS which had similar aposteriori results.

d) In the context of the RPS-model form, a linear model proved to be sufficient and including nonlinear terms did not in general improve the models.

e) In the context of the RPS-model form, including history did not significantly improve the accuracy of the models for this particular physical system. 

This project provided opportunities for training and professional development of graduate students and postdoctoral researchers in STEM related disciplines. In particular, this project allowed the graduate students and postdoctoral researchers to be equipped with skills relevant to scientific computing, mathematical modeling and probabilistic analysis. Such skills are valuable for enabling accurate computational predictions in a broad range of scientific and engineering disciplines.


Last Modified: 12/18/2017
Modified by: Peter J Attar
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The overall goal of this project was to formulate optimal, data-driven, reduced order models (ROMS) for significantly faster and more reliable computational predictions of nonlinear dynamical systems. These ROMS have the capability of improving the state-of-art in weak form based numerical discretizations. Most currently used ROMs in fields such as nonlinear structural dynamics, which are often based upon weak forms, do not consider the effects of the unresolved (temporal and spatial) scales on the resolved scales . Our work provides a methodology for including this important information through the use of data-driven subgrid models, which are based upon error minimization principles, and will hopefully motivate other researchers in this area to consider the concepts introduced in our work in their future research. Our ROM forms include the possibility of considering both current and past information (history), a concept which can be used to improve simulation accuracy and efficiency in many Engineering disciplines including the underresolved prediction of turbulent flows (large eddy simulation e.g. LES). Model forms investigated included a reduced polynomial (RPS-model; reduction based upon strain-displacement relationships for geometriclly nonlinear continuum mechanics) and a physics based model form (R-model). Two different methods for developing subgrid model in terms of error minimization were investigated. The first involves using apriori error minimization between the residual and the model for the residual (tau-error). The second (D-error) involves using aposteriori error, over a number of timesteps, between the filtered kinematic fields and the computed (with the subgrid model) kinematic fields. Our methodology was tested using a problem in nonlinear structural dynamics which consisted of a thin plate under a periodic point load. Multiple spatial and temporal scales were induced by the geometric nonlinearity of the plate, which was modeled using a finite element discretization based upon multi-field weak form. This problem was investigated numerically using both fully resolved simulation (FRS), which was used to both collect the spatiotemporal statistics necessary to construct the models and for aposteriori comparison, and underresolved model both with and without subgrid models. The following are some significant specific results for the problem simulated: a) For all model forms and minimization methods, ROMS with vastly reduced resolution (4 orders of magnitude fewer elements in comparison with fully resolved models and an order of magnitude reduction in temporal resolution) were able to be identified which were able to improve upon the results for computational models with same resolution but with no subgrid models. b) The R-model form, constructed using the D-error minimization procedure, produced results which best matched the filtered FRS results. c) The D-error and tau-error minimizations, in combination with the RPS model form, produced ROMS which had similar aposteriori results. d) In the context of the RPS-model form, a linear model proved to be sufficient and including nonlinear terms did not in general improve the models. e) In the context of the RPS-model form, including history did not significantly improve the accuracy of the models for this particular physical system. This project provided opportunities for training and professional development of graduate students and postdoctoral researchers in STEM related disciplines. In particular, this project allowed the graduate students and postdoctoral researchers to be equipped with skills relevant to scientific computing, mathematical modeling and probabilistic analysis. Such skills are valuable for enabling accurate computational predictions in a broad range of scientific and engineering disciplines. Last Modified: 12/18/2017 Submitted by: Peter J Attar
